ORDER
(Order of the Court was made by Mr.Justice S.MANIKUMAR)
Mr.Senthil Kumar, resident of Thalavaipuram, Rajapalayam Taluk,
Virudhunagar District, has filed this writ petition, for issuance of a Writ of
Mandamus, forbearing the respondents from undertaking any construction
activity in Survey No.50/2, Chettiyarpatti Village, Thalavaipuram, which has
been earmarked as Kalam Poromboke.
2.In the supporting affidavit, he has contended that in the village, there is
a temple called, Sithi Vinayagar temple, located on the southern side of Kalam
Poromboke (thrashing field). The field is surrounded by temples and all the
festivals are conducted in the thrashing field, by the village people. For their
village, there is a police station located near Thalavaipuram bus stand and it is

functioning for the past 20 years. On 12.02.2016, the Tahsildar, Rajapalayam
Taluk, Virudhunagar District, performed Boomi pooja, in the said Kalam
Poromboke. After enquiry, the villagers came to know that a new police station
is proposed to be constructed in the said place. They objected to the same. Even
in the Peace Committee Meeting convened, no settlement was arrived at. On
19.03.2016, despite objections, the respondents demolished the Kalam situated in
S.No.50/2, Chettiyarpatti Village, Thalavaipuram.
3.According to the petitioner, there are 2500 families living in the said
area. Agriculture is their main occupation. Kalam has been used for time
memorial days and alteration of the same would affect the villagers. thrashing
field at S.No.50/2, Chettiyarpatti Village, Thalavaipuram, is the place used by the
villagers both for agricultural purposes and to conduct public festivals. In the
abovesaid circumstances, Writ of Mandamus is sought for.
4.Considering the prayer sought for, we directed Mr.M.Alagadevan,
learned Special Government Pleader, to take notice on behalf of the respondents
and get instructions.

5.Reverting, he submitted that as early as on 06.10.2013 itself, the District
Collector, vide proceedings in Na.Ka.B4/11246/2012, dated 06.10.2013, has
accorded permission for transfer of lands, under Section 23-A of the Board
Standing Orders, measuring an extent of 0.05.0 hectare out of 0.41.0 hectare,
Kalam Poromboke in S.No.50/2, Chettiyarpatti Village, Thalavaipuram,
Rajapalayam Taluk, for construction of a police station. We further directed the
learned Special Government Pleader to produce the records.
6.Learned Special Government Pleader by placing reliance on the
documents and records enclosed in the typed set of papers, dated 31.03.2016,
submitted that all the objections raised in the present writ petition, do not merit
any consideration and prayed for dismissal for the writ petition.
7.Per contra, learned counsel for the petitioner submitted that there was
no consultation with Thalavaipuram Village Panchayat Council, nor there was
any resolution passed by the Council permitting transfer of land. Based on the
recent objections dated 22.03.2016, he further submitted that when 5 out of 9

ward members have objected to construction of a police station, the District
Collector, Virudhunagar, ought to have considered the same. It is also his
contention that the order of the District Collector passed without following the
procedure, is null and void, and for the abovesaid reasons, prayed to issue a
Writ of Mandamus.
Heard the learned counsel for the parties and perused the materials
available on record.
8.Section 134 of the Tamil Nadu Panchayats Act, 1994, reads as follows:-
''134. (1) The provisions of this section shall apply only in
ryotwari tracts.
(2) The following porambokes, namely, grazing grounds,
thrashing floors, burning and burial-grounds, cattle-stands, cart-
stands and topes shall vest in the village panchayat, and the village
panchayat shall have power, subject to such restrictions and control
as may be prescribed to regulate the use of such prorambokes,

provided the porambokes are at the disposal of the Government.
(3) The Collector, afler consulting the village panchayat,
may, by notification, exclude from the operation of this Act, any
poramboke referred to in sub-section (2), and may also modify or
cancel such notification.
(4) The village panchayat shall also have power, subject to
such restrictions and control as may be prescribed, to regulate the
use of any other poramboke which is at the disposal of the
Government, if the village panchayat is authorised in that behalf by
an order of the Government. (5) The village panchayat may, subject
to such restrictions and control as may be prescribed, plant trees on
any poramboke, the use of which is regulated by it under
subsection (2) or sub-section (4). ''
9.Government have issued orders in G.O(Ms)No.503, Revenue (Ni.Mu.
4-1) Department, dated 21.9.99, empowering the District Collectors to transfer
Government poromboke lands to the Government departments when requested
and the same reads as follows:-

10.The Superintendent of Police, Virudhunagar District, has submitted an
application requesting transfer of land for construction of a police station and
sought for appropriate orders. The application and covering letter read as
follows:-

11.Extract from the resolution book of the village panchayat shows that
the Council has passed a resolution No.203 on 03.10.2007 permitting
construction of police station in S.No.50/2.

12.Spot inspection has been done on 14.02.2008 and the report of the
Tahsildar, Rajapalayam Taluk reads as follows:-

13.Thereafter, the Tahsildar, Rajapalayam Taluk, in his letter
Roc.No.B5/4815/2007 dated 15.02.2008 has sent the particulars to the District
Revenue Officer, Virudhunagar District:-

14.Letter of the Revenue Divisional Officer, Sivagangai, addressed to the
District Revenue Officer, Virudhunagar District, reads as follows:-

15.Copy of the District Gazette both in Tamil and English have been
published excepting 0.05 H of land.

16.Vide letter dated 24.04.2011, the Director of Agriculture Department
has given consent for conversion of land and it is extracted hereunder:-
17.Thereafter, the District Collector, Virudhunagar District, has sent a
letter dated 15.06.2011 to the Principal Secretary and Commissioner for
Municipal Administration, Chennai and it reads as follows:-

18.Letter dated 26.07.2011 of the Principal Secretary and Commissioner of
Land Administration, Chennai, to the Principal Secretary to the Government,
Revenue Department, Chennai, reads thus.

19.Finally orders have been passed by the District Collector,
Virudhunagar District, in 2013, which reads as follows:-

20.From the extract from the typed set of papers dated 31.03.2016, it is
evident that the District Collector, Virudhunagar District, has followed the
procedure and transfer of land has been gazetted in Virudhunagar District
Gazette. Though the learned counsel for the petitioner submitted that there was
no proper consultation with Thalavaipuram Village Panchayat Council, copy of
the Resolution Book of Thalavaipuram Village Panchayat Council, enclosed in
the typedset of papers, filed by the respondents, shows that Thalavaipuram
Village Panchayat Council has passed a resolution on 03.10.2007, in Resolution
No.203, agreeing for transfer of lands, for the purpose of construction of a police
station.
21.Thalavaipuram Village Panchayat Council has passed a resolution way
back in 2007 and transfer of land has been effected by following the procedure.
Therefore, it is too late in the day, to make any objection, for construction of a
police station, by the present ward members. Moreover, thrashing field
measures 0.41.0 hectares in S.No.50/2. The extent of land allotted to the police,
for construction of a police station in the abovesaid S.No.50/2, is only 0.05.0

hectares, which is marginal. Contention of the petitioner that police station can
be constructed in some other place, cannot be accepted, as it is not for the
petitioner to say. It is for the District Administration and Police Department to
decide.
22.Going through the documents extracted supra, we are of the view that
there is no procedural impropriety. Public purpose is per se evident. The
decision taken by the district administration would not affect the livelihood of
the villagers as contended.
23.Writ of mandamus cannot be issued merely because a person is praying
for. One must first establish a right and then he must seek for the prayer to
enforce the said right. If there is failure of duty by the authorities or inaction,
one can approach the Court for a mandamus.
24.Though the petitioner has contended that the entire villagers would be
affected, by taking away a portion of the land, used by them, as thrashing field

and to conduct functions and festivals, having regard to the steps taken by the
departments right from the year 2007, which has culminated to an order in the
year 2013, this Court is not inclined to issue any mandamus as prayed for.
In the result, the writ petition is dismissed. No costs. Consequently,
W.M.P(MD)No.5231 of 2016 is closed.
(S.MANIKUMAR, J.) (C.T.SELVAM, J.)
05 th April 2016
